results.title: Computers and you
results.creator_credit: Journal Films and Reinald Werrenrath Jr
results.brief_description: In this film a computer display terminal and diagrams are used to explain, in simple terms, how a computer works and what it can do. A clear, visual explanation of how “bits” of information are given and instructions, flow charts, and information storage methods are explained. Suitable for teachers and tertiary level students.

results.title: Computers
results.creator_credit: ABC-TV (Australia), Sam Lipski and David Stiven
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Four corners (Television program)”.
Discusses the devleopment and increasing use of computers in Australia. Banks, the TAB, the stock exchange, aviation companies and many government social service departments are extensively computerised. Computers have an invaluable application in medical research and hospital services, and road traffic control. Presents the problem of redundant workers in a computerised community and questions the morality of a National Data Bank.

results.title: Computers
results.creator_credit: Bailey Film Productions and Victor and Ellen Landweber
results.brief_description: Describes the major components of a modern digital computer, and explores how the binary number system is useful in computer technology. The computer makes very rapid computations, and stores vast quantities of information.

results.title: Computer: tool for the future
results.creator_credit: National Geographic Society, Sidney Platt and Yves Gerard Issembert
results.brief_description: A look at the history of tools such as the abacus, adding machines and computers, the recent developments in computer technology and how computers are used to manage information and various applications of computers today. Also mentions some of the concerns that computerization raises.

results.title: Computer Space
results.brief_description: Computer Space is a video arcade game released in 1971 by Nutting Associates. Created by Nolan Bushnell and Ted Dabney, who would both later found Atari, Inc., it is generally accepted that it was the world’s first commercially sold coin-operated video game of any kind.

constellations_other.name: Arcades and AI
constellations_other.description: Using the godfather of computing, Alan Turing, as a starting point, this Constellation traces the evolution of AI representation on-screen and the way female androids, robots and holograms have been hyper sexualised.

results.description: Computer Space is a video arcade game released in 1971 by Nutting Associates. Created by Nolan Bushnell and Ted Dabney, who would both later found Atari, Inc., it is generally accepted that it was the world’s first commercially sold coin-operated video game of any kind, predating the Magnavox Odyssey’s release by six months, and Atari’s Pong by one year. It was first location tested at The Dutch Goose in August 1971, then debuted at the MOA show on October 15, 1971, and then officially released in November 1971. Though not commercially sold, the coin operated minicomputer-driven Galaxy Game appeared around the same time, located solely at Stanford University.
description_for_label: Computer Space is a video arcade game released in 1971 by Nutting Associates. Created by Nolan Bushnell and Ted Dabney, who would both later found Atari, Inc., it is generally accepted that it was the world’s first commercially sold coin-operated video game of any kind, predating the Magnavox Odyssey’s release by six months, and Atari’s Pong by one year. It was first location tested at The Dutch Goose in August 1971, then debuted at the MOA show on October 15, 1971, and then officially released in November 1971. Though not commercially sold, the coin operated minicomputer-driven Galaxy Game appeared around the same time, located solely at Stanford University.

results.title: Computer revolution. Parts 1 and 2
results.creator_credit: CBS, Isaac Kleinerman and James Jackson
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “21st Century”.
A timely - even frightening - reminder of the rapid advance computers are making into our lives. In many fields the impersonal efficient machine is shaping and controlling our destinies. The film points to the ever-increasing reliance on computers and illustrates computer applications of today and in the future specifically in production, aviation, medicine, education, law-enforcement, rocket space travel, design, communication etc. Implications for citizens’ rights to privacy. Reporter: Walter Cronkite.

results.title: Computer history digest: a chronicle of important events...
results.creator_credit: Association for computing machinery and George Samson
results.brief_description: Provides a brief historical overview of computers, with a focus on US achievements. Discusses punch card technology and the flexibility of plug boards. Shows the 1939 Worlds Fair showcasing future calculating devices and the ENIAC, designed by Eckert and Mauchly to compute World War II ballistic firing tables. Includes early 20th century footage of computers.

results.title: Computer Graphics Special
results.creator_credit: Geoffrey de Valois, Donna Cohen and Steve Michelson
results.brief_description: Journey to the unknown as this thoroughly entertaining program takes you on a behind the scenes journey into the exciting world of computer graphics and animation. Travel from inside the body to outer space; as the worlds of fantasy and reality explode in a colour and intensity never seen before.

results.title: Computer games
results.brief_description: ‘Computer games’ is a light-hearted drama about clashing personalities and computer crime in the corporate world. The director’s intention was to create a good, fun, entertaining film with a number of twists and surprises. The setting of the film is a high technology office environment where employee Raymond Edwards (David Whiteley) has one basic problem. For many years he has endured the company of Tony Simmons, a naive and aggravating workmate. Raymond’s experience is one to which many people can relate. He is frustrated by the constant annoying presence of a workmate who has followed him like a shadow through his career. Desperate to prevent Tony being considered for a promotion, Raymond frames him for embezzlement.
